awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Immune tradeoffs during tissue regeneration in mammals
awd_abstract_narration:
Why can salamanders re-grow amputated limbs but humans cannot? Understanding the mechanisms that favor tissue regeneration in lieu of tissue repair remains one of the great unanswered questions in biology.  A particularly intriguing hypothesis, though poorly investigated, is that the loss of regenerative capacity in higher vertebrates coincides with the presence of a strong adaptive immune response.  Now, the recent discovery of complete tissue regeneration in wild African spiny mice (Acomys) compared to the failure to regenerate in a co-occurring rodent (Myomyscus), allows a comprehensive examination of the links between immunity and regeneration in wild, pathogen-exposed, and fully immunocompetent adult mammals.  Specifically, this study tests the hypothesis that tradeoffs in immunity along (1) innate vs. adaptive and (2) pro vs. anti-inflammatory axes underlie variation in the ability and rate of regeneration between these wild species.  Quantifying immune and inflammatory changes at the cellular and molecular level in response to injury is expected to reveal a bias towards innate immunity and anti-inflammatory molecules in regenerators, and a shift towards adaptive immunity and pro-inflammatory responses in non-regenerators.  Project results will provide fundamental insight into the mechanisms that constrain regenerative ability in mammals.  
Because regeneration biology is a fascinating topic with great potential to excite students about science, the investigators will engage U.S. and international students of all ages in the project.  Graduate and undergraduate students from the U.S. will travel to Kenya, where animal work will take place, to actively participate in the study and collaborate with Kenyan students and scientists.  The project team will also make a series of visits to a local Kenyan girls' secondary school and a primary school to showcase basic concepts in regeneration biology using African spiny mice as a tool.  The international component of this study is co-supported by NSF's Office of International and Integrative Activities.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: This project focused on whether cellular and molecular tradeoffs in immunity underlie variation in the ability and rate of ear tissue regeneration. To examine this question we used a new mammalian model of regeneration, the African rodent (Acomys), and compared it to sympatric wild rodents and laboratory mice, neither of which are capable of regenerating tissue. One component of the project examined constitutive differences in innate, cellular immunity across multiple species of wild and captive mice (Acomys and Mus), focusing on neutrophil quantity and function. Neutrophils are central players in the acute inflammatory response to tissue injury. At wound sites, these cells kill pathogens via phagocytosis, degranulation, or the use of neutrophil extracellular traps, inflammatory processes that are hazardous to microbes but can also damage tissue potential compromising regeneration. Given the tissue-damaging side effects of neutrophil-mediated pathogen killing, we investigated whether these functions are constitutively dampened in Acomys compared to regeneration-incompetent mice. We found subtle differences in neutrophil traits (e.g. lower proportions of circulating neutrophils, higher phagocytosis activity, but no difference in reactive oxygen species production or migration ability), which may allow regeneration-competent species to offset damaging effects of inflammation without compromising pathogen defense.

Another way regeneration-competent species might offset the potential costs of inflammation is by relying more heavily on non-cellular (humoral) pathogen defense mechanisms. By partitioning microbial killing activity of Acomys and Mus into whole blood (neutrophils + serum), neutrophil only, and serum only components we found that microbial killing effects were dominated by serum activity in Acomys, whereas neutrophils appeared to dominate killing effects in Mus. Thus, a second component of the project explored variation in serum microbial killing ability in Acomys in comparison to sympatric wild rodents and Mus. Focusing on E. coli (strain ATCC #8739) as a focal microbe, we showed that Acomys microbial killing ability is consistently higher than other rodents. For example, serum killing activity tended to increase immediately after injury in Acomys, but not Mus. Across years, wild Acomys serum killing ability was consistently higher than Mus killing ability. Furthermore, dose-dependence experiments showed that across nine different dilutions of serum (1:1 to 1:256), the microbial killing performance of Acomys (measured as the serum concentration at which 50% microbial killing occurs, cumulative microbial growth across all dilutions, and the maximum killing at any dilution) consistently fell in the top half of all focal species examined. These results suggest that the enhancement of certain components humoral antimicrobial defense may be a strategy of Acomys that accompanies regeneration ability.

A third component of the project investigated the potential for biases in inflammatory and adaptive immune responses during the wound healing process. By characterizing and comparing cytokine responses during tissue regeneration in Acomys and fibrotic repair in Mus, we showed that injury induced a common set of pro-inflammatory cytokines across all species. However, fibrotic repair was associated with a greater release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, CCL2 and CXCL1). In contrast, there was a faster, stronger, and prolonged adaptive immune response during regeneration, revealed by a large influx of T cells into regenerating tissue and local increases in T-cell associated cytokines (IL-12 and IL-17). These results suggest that tissue regeneration in Acomys occurs in concert with a strong adaptive immune response.

Broader impacts: A key broader impact of this project was the training of students, including graduate and undergraduate students. Two MS theses were completed at the University of Georgia and a PhD student at the University of Nairobi received training. Six undergraduate and postgraduate students from the US and one Kenyan national were also trained. For a subset of the US students, training included hands-on research experience at the international field site in Kenya and one-on-one collaboration with partners at the University of Nairobi. Finally, a lasting impact of this project has been the enhancement of the research infrastructure in the Department of Veterinary Anatomy and Physiology at the University of Nairobi and strengthening of collaborative ties between researchers at the University of Georgia and University of Nairobi.
